title: Fourth Avenue (Brooklyn)
text:
Fourth Avenue is a major thoroughfare in the <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> <a href="Borough%20%28New%20York%20City%29">borough</a> of <a href="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a>. It stretches for south from <a href="Times%20Plaza">Times Plaza</a>, which is the triangle intersection created by <a href="Atlantic%20Avenue%20%28New%20York%20City%29">Atlantic</a> and <a href="Flatbush%20Avenue%20%28Brooklyn%29">Flatbush</a> Avenues in <a href="Downtown%20Brooklyn">Downtown Brooklyn</a>, to Shore Road and the <a href="Belt%20Parkway">Belt Parkway</a> in <a href="Bay%20Ridge%2C%20Brooklyn">Bay Ridge</a>.
While southwestern Brooklyn is well served by expressways, Fourth Avenue provides an alternate for local traffic as it directly links the neighborhoods of <a href="Park%20Slope%2C%20Brooklyn">Park Slope</a>, <a href="Sunset%20Park%2C%20Brooklyn">Sunset Park</a> and <a href="Bay%20Ridge%2C%20Brooklyn">Bay Ridge</a> with Downtown Brooklyn. Traffic signals along the avenue are coordinated for <a href="green%20wave">green wave</a> in the peak direction.
Description.
Fourth Avenue begins at <a href="Times%20Plaza">Times Plaza</a>, the triangle intersection it forms with Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues at the foot of the <a href="Williamsburgh%20Savings%20Bank%20Tower">Williamsburgh Savings Bank Tower</a> and <a href="Atlantic%20Terminal">Atlantic Terminal</a> in Downtown Brooklyn. The avenue extends south with three traffic lanes in each direction and a one-lane-wide concrete divider that provides a left-turn lane. The concrete divider is actually part of the ventilation system for the <a href="BMT%20Fourth%20Avenue%20Line">BMT Fourth Avenue Line</a>, which lies directly underneath. While six lanes are provided, only four lanes get full use, since the outer two are used by double-parked vehicles and as a right-turn lane.
On its course through <a href="Park%20Slope">Park Slope</a>, Fourth Avenue is home to several condominiums and homes but is dominated by service stations and automotive repair centers.
Upon entering <a href="Sunset%20Park%2C%20Brooklyn">Sunset Park</a>, Fourth Avenue passes under the <a href="Prospect%20Expressway">Prospect Expressway</a> (<a href="New%20York%20State%20Route%2027">NY 27</a>) and offers indirect access to it through local side streets. The avenue continues to serve the automotive trade as far as the street numbered in the low 40s, where it becomes flanked by large wall-to-wall apartment buildings.
After crossing under the <a href="Gowanus%20Expressway">Gowanus Expressway</a> viaduct into <a href="Bay%20Ridge%2C%20Brooklyn">Bay Ridge</a>, the arterial boulevard gives way to a four-lane street bordered by four- to five- story apartment buildings until it reaches Shore Road and the Belt Parkway under the <a href="Verrazano%20Narrows%20Bridge">Verrazano Narrows Bridge</a>.
History.
The avenue was paved in the 1890s as a grand <a href="parkway">parkway</a> resembling <a href="Park%20Avenue">Manhattan's Fourth Avenue</a>, which was later rebuilt and renamed to Park Avenue. The Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn was rebuilt after 1910 to accommodate more traffic.
On October 25, 1962, Mayor <a href="Robert%20F.%20Wagner%20Jr.">Robert F. Wagner Jr.</a> requested that the <a href="New%20York%20City%20Board%20of%20Estimate">New York City Board of Estimate</a> approve an expenditure of $724,572 for the reconstruction of subway structures and entrances along the <a href="BMT%20Fourth%20Avenue%20Line">Fourth Avenue subway line</a> in order to accommodate the widening of Fourth Avenue between 60th Street and Atlantic Avenue, which was to be accomplished by narrowing the street's sidewalks. At the time of the request, 80% of the work on the project was completed. Work had started on the project, which cost $1 million, several months earlier. The contract that the Mayor had requested approval for would have relocated vault lights, gratings, entrances and exits at 56th Street and 49th Street, and at the 45th Street, 53rd Street and 59th Street stations.
Protected <a href="Bike%20lane">bike lanes</a>, separated from vehicular traffic by a lane of parking, were proposed for Fourth Avenue in 2017 in an attempt to improve <a href="Cycling%20in%20New%20York%20City">cycling infrastructure in New York City</a>. The first bike lanes were added between 60th and 64th Streets within Sunset Park in 2018, followed by the section between 1st and 15th Streets in Park Slope in early 2019. Due to ongoing reconstruction work on the Fourth Avenue subway tunnel, the section between 60th and 38th Streets could not receive bike lanes until the reconstruction was completed. In August 2019, following several cyclist deaths citywide, the <a href="New%20York%20City%20Department%20of%20Transportation">NYCDOT</a> announced that the remainder of Fourth Avenue between 38th and 60th Streets would receive protected bike lanes by late 2020.
Churches.
The borough has a thoroughfare named <a href="Brooklyn%20streets%20by%20neighborhood">Church Avenue</a> (named for an <a href="Flatbush%20Dutch%20Reformed%20Church%20Complex">18th-century church</a>), which, contrary to its name, does not rival the large number of later churches located along Fourth Avenue. At Fourth Avenue's intersection with 54th Street in Sunset Park, there are four houses of worship either directly at the corner of the intersection or within a building of it. Two of the churches stand side by side.
Public transportation.
The <a href="BMT%20Fourth%20Avenue%20Line">BMT Fourth Avenue Line</a> () of the <a href="New%20York%20City%20Subway">New York City Subway</a> runs the length of Fourth Avenue. Stations are located at <a href="Atlantic%20Avenue%20%E2%80%93%20Barclays%20Center%20%28BMT%20Fourth%20Avenue%20Line%29">Atlantic Avenue</a>, <a href="Union%20Street%20%28BMT%20Fourth%20Avenue%20Line%29">Union Street</a>, <a href="Ninth%20Street%20%28BMT%20Fourth%20Avenue%20Line%29">Ninth Street</a>, <a href="Prospect%20Avenue%20%28BMT%20Fourth%20Avenue%20Line%29">Prospect Avenue</a>, <a href="25th%20Street%20%28BMT%20Fourth%20Avenue%20Line%29">25th Street</a>, <a href="36th%20Street%20%28BMT%20Fourth%20Avenue%20Line%29">36th Street</a>, <a href="45th%20Street%20%28BMT%20Fourth%20Avenue%20Line%29">45th Street</a>, <a href="53rd%20Street%20%28BMT%20Fourth%20Avenue%20Line%29">53rd Street</a>, <a href="59th%20Street%20%28BMT%20Fourth%20Avenue%20Line%29">59th Street</a>, <a href="Bay%20Ridge%20Avenue%20%28BMT%20Fourth%20Avenue%20Line%29">Bay Ridge Avenue</a>, <a href="77th%20Street%20%28BMT%20Fourth%20Avenue%20Line%29">77th Street</a>, <a href="86th%20Street%20%28BMT%20Fourth%20Avenue%20Line%29">86th Street</a>, and <a href="Bay%20Ridge%20%E2%80%93%2095th%20Street%20%28BMT%20Fourth%20Avenue%20Line%29">95th Street</a>, with express stations at Atlantic Avenue, 36th Street, and 59th Street.
<a href="MTA%20Regional%20Bus%20Operations">MTA Regional Bus Operations</a> operates several routes, none of which serve the avenue significantly. The Limited route has the longest stretch, traveling southbound on 4th Avenue from Atlantic Avenue to Prospect Expressway. The also use the avenue for short stretches. The also stop at the south end of the avenue.
